text.tspan: Some of the world's most pressing problems can be traced to inequity between people, both in the present and over time. Long periods of inequity can lead to
both social and environmental degradation. In its 2011 Human Development Report (HDR), the United Nations incisively examines some of the complex relation
ships between socioeconomic equity and environmental sustainability. This visualization, by members of the MIT Media Lab and The DuKode Studio, organizes
some of the HDRâ€™s summative indicators into network graphs to show how nations are multi-dimensionally linked within these relationships. Perhaps these links
can encourage intercultural discussions in the global effort for a world that is more equal today and more sustainable over time.
Node Color = Americas | Europe | Asia | Africa
Node Size = Loss in potential human development*
Node Grouping: Upper, middle, and lower thirds for checked indicators. A composite value is used when multiple indicators are checked.
Rollovers: A Nation-Node's neighbors are shown for checked indicators. Thick outlines indicate the next larger value, while thin outlines indicate the next
smaller value. Nation-Node details are also displayed upon rollover.
*The percent difference between the Human Development Index (HDI) and Inequality-Adjusted Human Development Index (IHDI). See UN HDR 2011, p. 138.

svg.text: Neighbors and Networks in Equity and Sustainability
